title-group.article-title: GOVERNMENT SIZE AND MONETARY POLICY: INTERACTIONS AND PRODUCTIVITY IN THE ECONOMIES OF GCC COUNTRIES

abstract.p: The main objective of this study is to examine the relationship between government spending and growth in the countries of the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC). The framework of the paper extends the efforts begun in an earlier study by providing evidence on how the size of government explains the differences in growth across GCC countries. The methodology in the first part is focused on the interaction between government spending and major shocks in the economic system, mainly the shocks to monetary growth and the growth of private spending on consumption and investment. In the second part, an aggregate production function approach is utilized where national output is a function of capital, labor, and government services. Several hypotheses are tested to see if government spending is productive on average and overall. Also, government spending is decomposed into five major components: social services, public services, economic activities, defense and security, and others. The productivity of each type of these government spending is also examined.
